We‚Äôre very appreciative of our open source contributors üíö Thank you Muhammad Ahmad Shoukat for your hard work on Open Canvas!

Muhammad Ahmad Shoukat

Full-Stack AI Engineer | Voice & Multi-Agent Systems | Canvas-Style AI Interfaces | Available for Project

Just received my swag from LangChain for my contributions to Open Canvas! A big thank you to Brace Sproul and the entire LangChain team‚Äîthis recognition truly means a lot. Contributing to open source is not just about giving back; it‚Äôs a great way to learn and grow professionally. I‚Äôm eager to continue building innovative features together! Also, a special thanks to Zia Khan for your continuous mentorship and support. #OpenSource #LangChain #AI

data.snippet:
# Brace Sproul‚Äôs Post

Brace Sproul

Head of Applied AI @ LangChain

 Report this post

Incredibly exciting to see LangChain recognized by Forbes in their AI50 list!

LangChain

466,888 followers

We‚Äôre excited to share that LangChain has been named to the 2025 Forbes AI 50 list! Produced in partnership with Sequoia and Meritech Capital, the list spotlights the most promising privately-held AI companies in the world. It‚Äôs an honor to be recognized alongside many of our customers‚Äîsuch as Clay, Mercor, and Writer‚Äîwho are shaping the future of AI. See the list ‚û°Ô∏è  We're hiring! Join the team ü§ù

data.title: The 2004 YMCA Hall of Fame Induction Program
data.snippet: Brace was also highly regarded for his expertise in staff building. He was skilled at assembling strong teams of individ-uals to serve as managers, and combining those peo-ple with efficient administrative support. Brace, through his commitment to ongoing training and goal setting, created an environment of independent thinking individuals who also served as an extremely cohesive staff. The result of Brace‚Äôs person-centered leadership technique was a high level of morale in the Ys in which he served. In 1999, the Rotary Club of Charlotte posthumously honored Brace with its Excellence in Management Award. Brace would conclude his Y career at the YMCA of Greater Charlotte in Charlotte, North Carolina, where he served as president for more than sixteen years. Brace, described as possessing a [...] and volunteer participation in the YMCA, and exemplified the ideals of the YMCA and Springfield College in his or her personal and professional life. In recognition of Springfield College‚Äôs historic partner-ship with the YMCA, dating back to Ôú±Ôú∏Ôú∏Ôúµ, the Advisory Council and Hall of Fame Committee chose the College as the site for the YMCA Hall of Fame. The Hall of Fame has been endorsed and supported by the YMCA of the USA, the National Council of the YMCA of Canada, and the YMCA Retirement Fund. The Hall of Fame Committee has reviewed nomina-tions submitted by executives throughout the USA and Canada and has unanimously elected Richard Bailey, Harry H. Brace, James F. Bunting, and Richard W. MacMorran for induction into the YMCA Hall of Fame at Springfield College Richard Bailey‚Äôs career [...] more than sixteen years. Brace, described as possessing a unique mix of respect for his colleagues and sound business sense, led the YMCA of Greater Charlotte to a membership increase from 45,994 to more than 106,000 between the years 1983 and 1999. Under Brace‚Äôs leadership, the Ys budget grew from $5 million to $40 million during that same time. With Brace leading the way, the YMCA of Greater Charlotte became one of the most successful Ys in the country, recognized not only by Y officials and fitness experts, but also by children and families alike. Brace and his staff throughout the years focused on creating better communities. Following in his father‚Äôs footsteps led Brace to a distinguished 40-year career with the YMCA. He believed in, and was committed to, the ideal of spirit, mind,

data.title: ÂçöÂÆ¢Â∏ñÂ≠ê - Becca Rothfeld
data.snippet: The Baffler, and more. These days, I write mostly for the Washington Post about non-fiction, but occasionally I write essays on fiction and whatever else for other venues. I am the winner of the first annual Robert B. Silvers Prize for Literary Criticism (see more here) and the 2023 Nona Balakian Citation for Excellence in Reviewing (see more here).  In 2017, I was a finalist for a National Magazine Award in the essays/criticism category. A few authors I especially love are Joseph Roth, Italo Svevo, Henry James, Henry Green, Heinrich von Kleist, Marie de France, and Norman Rush. My agent is Anna Sproul-Latimer of Neon Literary.  As a (lapsed?) philosopher: I am primarily interested in aesthetics (especially aesthetic value and its relationship to other types of value), the philosophy of [...] on a much grander scale, to the famously desirable model and actor Emily Ratajkowski. As she recounts in her debut essay collection, My Body, a fashion photographer who took nude pictures of her when she was young, drunk and vulnerable persists in selling books of the Polaroids. Read more here.    0 Comments  I wrote about Franzen (whom I like--sorry!) for The Atlantic 10/4/2021  2 Comments        2 Comments  I wrote about Tisma for the New Left Review 9/30/2021  0 Comments    In The Use of Man (1976), the second instalment of Serbo-Croatian novelist Aleksandar Ti≈°ma‚Äôs Novi Sad trilogy, a schoolboy stares at the books in his Jewish neighbour‚Äôs library on the eve of World War II ‚Äòas if they contained the clues to salvation, as if they could rescue one from being beaten, cursed, spat upon, [...] Post's 50 Notable Works of Non-Fiction from 2024. Finally, I am also a PhD candidate (on indefinite hiatus) in philosophy at Harvard, but i remain perhaps delusionally convinced that someday I will finish my dissertation. These days I live in Washington, DC, with this person, whom I love. Here you can find all of my Washington Post pieces, which will come out each week, generally speaking. To keep up with my writing/rantings, subscribe to my substack here.   As a writer:  I have contributed essays, book reviews, and the occasional art review to publications like The TLS, The London Review of Books, The Nation, The New York Times Book Review, The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Liberties, Bookforum, Art in America, The Yale Review, The Drift, The Baffler, and more. These days, I write mostly for
